question: Question_05_(b)
statement:
5. The function $e^{i\pi x}$ for x $\varepsilon$ {[}0, 1{]} can be
expanded in a Fourier series

$e^{i\pi x}$ = $\sum_{n=-\propto }^{\propto }c _{n} e^{2\pi inx}$

(b){[}this part should worth 7 points{]}

Suppose $\phi _{0}$(x), $\phi _{1}$(x), $\phi _{2}$(x),... is an
infinite orthonormal basis of functions on the interval {[}0,1{]} and we
have the expansion

$e^{i\pi x} = \sum_{n=0}^{\propto }d _{n} \phi _{n}(x).$

Suppose, in addition, that $\phi _{0}$ is the constant function
$\phi _{0}$(x) = 1. Is it true that $d_{0}$ = $c_{0}$, where $c_{0}$ is
the Fourier coefficient above? Give a reason.
sols:
We have:

\begin{align*}
e^{i\pi x} &= \sum_{n=-\propto }^{\propto }c _{n} e^{2\pi inx}\\
&= c_{0} + \sum_{n=-\propto }^{-1}c_{n}e^{2\pi inx}+\sum_{n=1}^{\propto }c_{n}e^{2\pi inx}\\
&= c_{0}+\sum_{n=1}^{\propto }c_{-n}e^{-2\pi inx} + \sum_{n=1}^{\propto }c_{n}e^{2\pi inx}\\
&= c_{0} + \sum_{n=1}^{\propto }c_{n}e^{2\pi inx} + c_{-n}e^{-2\pi inx}
\end{align*}

We also have:

\begin{align*}
e^{i\pi x} &= \sum_{n=0}^{\propto }d _{n} \phi _{n}(x)\\
&= d_{0}\phi _{0}(x) + \sum_{n=1}^{\propto }d_{n}\phi _{n}(x)\\
&= d_{0} + \sum_{n=1}^{\propto }d_{n}\phi _{n}(x)
\end{align*}

Since $\phi _{0}$(x), $\phi _{1}$(x), $\phi _{2}$(x),... is an infinite
orthonormal basis, then $\phi _{n}$ spans functions in interval
{[}0,1{]}, thus $\sum_{n=1}^{\propto }d_{n}\phi _{n}(x)$ gives all
possible components(except for n=0) of $e^{i\pi x}$. Also,
$\sum_{n=1}^{\propto }c_{n}e^{2\pi ix} + c_{-n}e^{-2\pi ix}$ gives all
possible components(except for n=0) of $e^{i\pi x}$. Therefore if

$e^{2\pi ix} = c_{0} + \sum_{n=1}^{\propto }c_{n}e^{2\pi ix} + c_{-n}e^{-2\pi ix} = d_{0} + \sum_{n=1}^{\propto }d_{n}\phi _{n}(x)$,

we must have $c_{0} = d_{0}$.
